name: Shimla
fun_fact: Fun fact: Shimla was the summer capital of British India, and its cuisine reflects a unique blend of British colonial, Punjabi, Tibetan, and indigenous Himachali traditions. The city sits at 2,200m elevation in the Himalayan foothills!

hero_dishes.name: Himachali Dham
hero_dishes.description: The crown jewel feast featuring 15-20 dishes served on traditional brass plates lined with pattal (leaf plates). Includes Madhara, Mah Ki Dal, Kaddu Ka Khatta, and more. All cooked in brass over woodfire.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This elaborate ceremonial feast is prepared by special chefs called 'botis' using ancient techniques. Begins with a sweet dish and progresses through numerous preparations, all with distinctive smoky flavor from wood-fire cooking.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Himachali Rasoi on Mall Road Middle Bazaar for authentic Pahadi thali; traditionally served at festivals and special occasions throughout Shimla

hero_dishes.name: Chha Gosht
hero_dishes.description: Robust mutton curry slow-cooked with yogurt and a secret blend of mountain herbs. Rich, aromatic, and particularly popular during winter.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A highlander specialty from the narrow lanes of Lower Bazaar, this dish has become synonymous with Shimla's food culture, warming residents through harsh Himalayan winters.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Vendors in Lower Bazaar; traditional highland restaurants throughout Shimla, especially in winter months

hero_dishes.name: Siddu
hero_dishes.description: Steamed wheat bread with poppy seed filling, requiring precise fermentation timing. Served with generous ghee and spicy green chutney.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Represents the ingenuity of Himachali cuisine - a skillfully fermented bread that showcases the region's wheat and the delicate balance required in mountain cooking.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Himachali Rasoi for classic preparations; local highland restaurants specializing in authentic Pahadi cuisine

hero_dishes.name: Momos (Tibetan Influence)
hero_dishes.description: Dumplings with various fillings from classic vegetables to innovative potato-cheese combinations, including special Himachali momos with local spices.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Shimla is an important Tibetan colony, and momos have become integral to street food culture, adapted with Himachali spicing.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Best spots along Mall Road, particularly near Scandal Point area; street vendors throughout the city

signature_drinks.name: Masala Chai with Herbs
signature_drinks.description: Traditional masala tea with aromatic herbs and spices - cardamom, cinnamon, ginger - brewed with black tea, milk, and sugar.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served at Honey Hut cafe where it's made with honey; Indian Coffee House (since 1957) for classic masala chai; essential morning and afternoon beverage throughout the hill station

signature_drinks.name: Apple Cider and Fruit Wines
signature_drinks.description: Locally produced apple cider and fruit wines from Himachal Pradesh, India's fruit bowl. Made from apples, plums, apricots, and peaches.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: HPMC (Himachal Pradesh Horticultural Produce Marketing Corporation) produces high-quality apple cider from Shimla district apples. Look for locally made fruit wines - surprisingly good quality from the fertile mountain region

food_culture_notes: Cuisine is homely yet rich and intense, using lentils, rice, pulses, wheat bread, and predominantly red meat
British colonial influence blends with Punjabi, Tibetan, and indigenous Himachali practices
Being an important Tibetan colony, regional food is highly inspired by Tibetan culture
Special chefs called 'botis' prepare traditional Dham feasts
All Dham dishes cooked in brass utensils over woodfire for smoky flavor
Shimla sits in India's fruit bowl with excellent apple production

landmarks: Mall Road with shops and restaurants
unique_modern: Blend of four culinary cultures in one city
Hill station cafe culture with Himalayan views
